I first read it when I was in 7th grade when my English was not that good. English is like my third language so I could understand it enough to know that Lizzie would end up with Mr Darcy but didn't understand Mr Wickham's story(I remember often confusing Colonel Fitzwilliam with him lol) . I watched the movies several years after that. Now that my English is better, I would give anything to read the book for the first time:(

I actually saw the 1995 adaptation before I read the book. I had decided that I wanted to know more about classic lit but chose to watch P&P first because I‚Äôm thirstyyyy for Colin Firth lol. Thing is, I did so whilst thinking that the little I knew of the plot of Jane Eyre was actually about P&P so I spent the whole series thinking Elizabeth was gonna find or become Mrs Darcy stuck in an attic..? So let‚Äôs just say I was very relieved but confused by the HEA for Darcy and Elizabeth :)

I‚Äôm not sure if it was meant to be a big twist but I was pretty certain the first time reading through that she‚Äôd come around to Darcy and he end up not being a bad guy. I can‚Äôt say much else though because I ended up watching the BBC show and the movie before I finished the rest of the book.
I think that‚Äôs what I thought, too. Thanks for commenting!
Thanks for commenting! Can totally see that perspective! Bingley and the Bingley/Jane relationship are really the catalyst I think

I actually first read the book believing that the story revolved around Jane and Bingley. Yes, I know. There was no summary or anything, and the book was an ancient copy from 1952 or something which just had a man holding out a letter to a lady on the front. I had no expectations ever and I was solely reading it because I was bored and my friend managed to smuggle it out of a library ( don't worry, it's where it belongs now). When I fist read it, I was solely on Lizzie's side. Wickham actually seemed really nice and when the big revelation came, it fell on me like how it fell on lizzie and the first readers. I actually couldn't believe it when he eloped with Lydia. But I loved Mr.Darcy and Elizabeth together anyway because of all those exchanges they have and was really happy in the end. I would love to make people read it without any foreknowledge of the plot because that just makes you feel like how Austen would have liked you to feel. Still the best book I've ever read in my life.

Ah! Don‚Äôt read any more on this sub!

I mean, obviously do what you wish and what is best but I don‚Äôt want to give any spoilers if you don‚Äôt know anything. It‚Äôs no thriller but still! Thanks for commenting

Shes saying that it doesn't matter how well you know your spouse before getting married, because you'll be married for the rest of your life and people change over time. Basically, if you marry for love now, it might not do you any good in a decade or two because you'll be different people by then. If you decide to marry for practical reasons and make the choice to be happy with your life, those reasons will still hold up over time.

I guess the reason it would inspire so much fanfic is that it is so loved by many generations for multiple reasons; it has a good message, relatable characters, great wit, etc. I love the fact that P&P has so much fanfic and new takes on Austen's original story and characters as it gives me new ways to enjoy one of my favourites. In fact, it was the movie Pride and Prejudice and Zombies that got me into Jane Austen, to begin with, so yay for fanfics lol.

What's great is that is the point of the book, that he wounded her pride and she couldn't see him through any other lens - at first. Honestly don't blame her either and I would be the same way - even after reading a book about putting aside our wounded pride and prejudices against people.
